messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 44 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Transferring Experience from Simulation to the Real World for Precise Pick-And-Place Tasks in Highly Cluttered Scenes

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper, we introduce a novel learning-based approach for grasping known rigid objects in highly cluttered scenes and precisely placing them based on depth images. Our Placement Quality Network (PQ-Net) estimates the object pose and the quality for each automatically generated grasp pose for multiple objects simultaneously at 92 fps in a single forward pass of a neural network. All grasping and placement trials are executed in a physics simulation and the gained experience is transferred to the real world using domain randomization. We demonstrate that our policy successfully transfers to the real world. PQ-Net outperforms other model-free approaches in terms of grasping success rate and automatically scales to new objects of arbitrary symmetry without any human intervention.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 44 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 44"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Deep object pose estimation for semantic robotic grasping of household objects",
        "Deep learning for detecting robotic grasps",
        "Real-time grasp detection using convolutional neural networks",
        "Jacquard: A large scale dataset for robotic grasp detection",
        "Gripping point determination and collision prevention in a bin-picking application",
        "Gripping point determination for bin picking using heuristic search",
        "Closing the loop for robotic grasping: A real-time, generative grasp synthesis approach",
        "Learning hand-eye coordination for robotic grasping with deep learning and large-scale data collection",
        "Supersizing self-supervision: Learning to grasp from 50k tries and 700 robot hours",
        "QT-Opt: Scalable deep reinforcement learning for vision-based robotic manipulation",
        "Domain randomization for transferring deep neural networks from simulation to the real world",
        "Dex-Net 1.0: A cloud-based network of 3d objects for robust grasp planning using a multi-armed bandit model with correlated rewards",
        "Dex-Net 2.0: Deep learning to plan robust grasps with synthetic point clouds and analytic grasp metrics",
        "Dex-Net 3.0: Computing robust vacuum suction grasp targets in point clouds using a new analytic model and deep learning",
        "Intelligent picking of chaotically stored objects",
        "A survey on learning-based robotic grasping",
        "Simulation-driven machine learning for robotics and automation",
        "Partikel-Schwarm-Optimierung zur Objektlageerkennung in Tiefendaten",
        "Heuristisches Suchverfahren zur Objektlageerkennung aus Punktewolken für industrielle Zuführsysteme",
        "You Only Look Once: Unified, real-time object detection",
        "YOLO9000: Better, faster, stronger",
        "SSD: Single shot multibox detector",
        "Real-time seamless single shot 6d object pose prediction",
        "Single shot 6d object pose estimation",
        "Symmetry aware evaluation of 3d object detection and pose estimation in scenes of many parts in bulk",
        "Large-scale 6d object pose estimation dataset for industrial bin-picking",
        "An overview of 3d object grasp synthesis algorithms",
        "Data-driven grasp synthesis—a survey",
        "Real-time 6d object pose estimation on cpu",
        "Efficient grasping from rgbd images: Learning using a new rectangle representation",
        "Learning robust, real-time, reactive robotic grasping",
        "Using simulation and domain adaptation to improve efficiency of deep robotic grasping",
        "Sim-to-real via sim-to-sim: Data-efficient robotic grasping via randomized-to-canonical adaptation networks",
        "Multi-view picking: Next-best-view reaching for improved grasping in clutter",
        "Improving data efficiency of self-supervised learning for robotic grasping",
        "Faster k-medoids clustering: Improving the pam, clara, and clarans algorithms",
        "V-REP: A versatile and scalable robot simulation framework",
        "The open motion planning library",
        "Defining the pose of any 3d rigid object and an associated distance",
        "Increasing the grasp reliability for bin picking by using machine learning",
        "Densely connected convolutional networks",
        "RG2 – flexible 2 finger robot gripper with wide stroke.",
        "Learning based robotic bin-picking for potentially tangled objects",
        "Increasing the robustness of random bin picking by avoiding grasps of entangled workpieces"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 44 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Transferring Experience from Simulation to the Real World for Precise Pick-And-Place Tasks in Highly Cluttered Scenes, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
